sub_title: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)
summary: Academic think tanker, interested in diplomacy and its role in international politics: I research, write, mentor, teach, speak, and more. Other affiliations: Centre on Public Diplomacy, USC, Los Angeles. Recommeded: follow The Hague Journal of Diplomacy on LinkedIn and Twitter.

treasury_media.title: @Hague_Jour_Dipl
treasury_media.description: The leading research journal for the study of diplomacy.

treasury_media.title: Public Diplomacy and Soft Power in East Asia

projects.title: Domestic Engagement in Diplomatic Affairs
projects.description: This book project enquires the rise of domestic public engagement in diplomatic affairs, which has altered the conventional wisdom on two-level games between diplomacy and domestic politics. The informal political sphere has become more important, people as the smallest units of society have greater agency and the domestic public has become a more important factor in diplomatic considerations. This multi-disciplinary project aims to further open academic research to the home dimension of diplomacy. Contributors will explore the multi-faceted nature of state-society dialogues, different theoretical approaches that can be applied to this emerging phenomenon, and to what extent diplomatic practices and foreign policy are shaped by state-society relations. See our confirmed participants.

projects.title: The Hague Journal of Diplomacy Events
projects.description: The Hague Journal of Diplomacy organizes annual public events and closed seminars on diplomacy's contribution to international politics and trends in diplomatic practice. Our 2023 events: 1) "The Hague Space Diplomacy Symposium", an international public seminar at Leiden's Institute of Security and Global Affairs in The Hague (12th June), and 2) "Caste and Diplomacy", a closed authors' workshop hosted by the Leiden University Institute for History (22-23 May).

projects.title: The LGBT Diplomat
projects.description: This research project will create a novel account of the influence of sexual orientation on how diplomats practice diplomacy. It is inspired by scholarship on queer IR and gender and diplomacy, and motivated by the lack of a sexuality component in the literature on diplomacy. Our research points toward a strong relationship between sexual orientation and diplomacy, as a result of both the personal identity of the diplomat as well as a range other factors. The project and its conclusion speak to wider discussions about foreign policy, change in diplomatic practice and organisational diversity and inclusion.

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)
Junior Public Affairs Advisor

projects.title: Social Capital Creation in Western Celebrity Diplomacy
projects.description: This project aims to bring conceptual and theoretical clarity from a diplomatic studies perspective, by providing empirical research that further enhances our understanding of celebrity diplomacy in the digital realm. We question how Western celebrity diplomats can co-create social capital in the form of transnational political participation, shifting focus from policy change to engagement.

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)
Project Manager Challenge Based Education at TU Delft || Media Editor at The Hague Journal of Diplomacy

projects.title: Participatory Diplomacy: State-Society Relations in Diplomatic Practice
projects.description: This is a study of state dialogue with the public on issues in international affairs. It will consist of conceptual and theoretical work, as well as case studies. Increased domestic orientation of foreign ministries can be observed in states across the world. Relations between the state and the people in domestic society therefore deserves to be part of the narrative on diplomacy.

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)
Researcher | Communications Consultant

projects.title: The Hague Journal of Diplomacy Forums
projects.description:
The Hague Journal of Diplomacy Forums are a collaborative effort of the HJD Editor-in-Chief, Associate Editors and Guest Editor(s). The Forums are debate-oriented and discuss the role of diplomacy in international politics as well as new avenues for future research. Forums in HJD planning for 2023-5 are on: Space Diplomacy (guest editors: Mai'a Cross and Saadia Pekkanen); Cyber Diplomacy (guest editors: Joe Burton, George Christou, Joachim Koops, Wilhelm Vosse); Embassy Architecture and Diplomatic  Practice (guest editors: Stuart MacDonald  and Shaun Riordan) ; The Future of Diplomatic Studies (guest editors: Rebecca Adler-Nissen and Jan Melissen). 


See for regular updates on HJD Forums: https://www.universiteitleiden.nl/hjd/journal/forum-essays or  www.brill.com/hjd

projects.title: PhD Supervision of Research on Diplomacy in Theory and Practice
projects.description: I am supervising PhD Projects on Diplomacy and I welcome strong proposals. PhD students who have obtained their doctorate are: Maaike Okano-Heijmans (economic diplomacy and the case of Japan); Ingrid d'Hooghe (China's public diplomacy); Manuel Duran (sub-state diplomacy in Europe); Arjan Uilenreef (bilateral diplomacy in the EU); Kim Olsen (geo-economic diplomacy, Jane Knight (knowledge diplomacy). Ceck out their more recent academic work and contributions to the public debate.

projects.title: Oxford Bibliography - Public Diplomacy
projects.description: This article in the Oxford Bibliographies section on International Relations contains well over 100 titles in 14 thematic sections and each one of them with a short commentary. Our selection of articles is limited to academic publications in the English language and mainly published after 2010.  The article offers our take on cutting-edge research in a fast-evolving and multidisciplinary field. I would welcome your suggestions on additional categories that would make this bibliography more reflective of important 21st century work in this thriving field of research in diplomatic studies.

projects.title: Ministries of Foreign Affairs in the World
projects.description: Two outputs: Hague Journal of Diplomacy Special Issue (2020:1-2) and an edited book in the Brill Diplomatic Studies series. This project makes a case for debating MFAs’ institutional responses to change in their internal and external environment. It has contributions from Asia, Europe and Central America, and pays attention to a variety of perspectives, including ethnicity, gender and technology.

Professeur de science politique chez Sciences Po

projects.title: China's Global Diplomacy
projects.description: This is a Special Issue of The Hague Journal of Diplomacy (16;2-3, 2021) co-edited by Qingmin Zhang, Peking University, China, Paul Sharp, University of Minnesota, Duluth, United States, and Jan Melissen, Institute of Security and Global Affairs, Leiden University, the Netherlands. The special issue has two sections, one with five research articles and another one with five HJD Forum essays. 60 per cent of the content is from China and 40 per cent has been written by Western authors.

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)

projects.title: Chinese Celebrity Diplomacy
projects.description: Article published in International Affairs. We examine Chinese celebrities' UN-affiliated Weibo activism in the context of China's increasing  engagement with the United Nations. Although accredited by the UN, Chinese celebrities' activism has become more symbolic than real, and as a rule aligned with the Chinese leadership's domestic and international ambitions.

projects.title: The First Consular Challenge: Communicating Assistance to Nationals Abroad
projects.description: This research has been commissioned by the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I argue that the communicative challenge is the main hurdle for consular diplomacy in the digital age. Governments are well advised to go about this activity in a more citizen-centric fashion and based on a deeper understanding of their nationals’ communicative behaviour. The results of this research have been published in Asia & the Pacific Policy Studies 7:2 (2020). See the URL above for Open Access.

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)

projects.title: Rebel Diplomacy and Digital Communication
projects.description: This research has been published in International Affairs (see URL above). We analyse how rebel groups choose to interact with foreign audiences, why do they do it, and what factors may explain variation in such strategic communications. Social media have transformed what it means to have power and a voice on the international stage. This study distinguishes between different types of violent groups with different aims and ideologies. Our research contributes to the study of public diplomacy and digital diplomacy by non-state actors outside the Western world.

Advisor Low Carbon Fuels at Shell - views are my own

projects.title: Debating Public Diplomacy: Now and Next
projects.description: The Hague Journal of Diplomacy's double special issue on the future of public diplomacy is the main deliberable of this project, which will be online by the end of 2018. This is a much-needed effort to update the narrative on public diplomacy. The future-oriented essays are authoritative in analysis and accessible in style. Contributors come from North America, the Asia-Pacific and Europe. Co-Editors: Jay Wang and Jan Melissen. The paperback edition (September 2019) with the same contents as this special issue has an additional detailed index.

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)

projects.title: Korean diplomacy: soft power, domestic and peninsular challenges
projects.description: See our KIEP BRIEF in the project URL. The first leg of thosresearch project is centered on a Visiting Scholarship granted by the Korean Institute of International Economic Policy (KIEP) in 2018. South Korean diplomacy is constrained by peninsular concerns and recovering from the national political trauma in 2016-17. This project takes stock of how the South Korean government is dealing with key foreign policy challenges, in particular how they offer a window for diplomatic innovation.

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)

projects.title: Diplomacy in the 21st Century
projects.description: This is a project with an international working group coordinated by the think tank Stiftung Wissenschaft und Politik (SWP) in Berlin. The objective of the group, headed by Dr Volker Stanzel, is to identify how diplomacy is adapting to new realities in foreign affairs. The project's research papers re available online at SWP. The book, "New Realities in Foreign Affairs; Diplomacy in the 21st Century" has been also been published in German as "Die neue Wirklichkeit der Aussenpolitik: Diplomatie im 21. Jahrhundert". My chapter, co-authored with Emillie de Keulenaar is on "Critical Digital Diplomacy and How Theory Can Inform Practice".

contributors.headline: Editor-in-Chief The Hague Journal of Diplomacy - Senior Fellow and Professor - Leiden University (NL) and University of Antwerp (B)
PhD at RUG and Research Consultant at UN Innovation Network

projects.title: Foreign Ministries, SDGs and the Private Sector
projects.description: This research project has been commissioned by the Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs has led to various publications, including an article for GLOBAL POLICY (September 2018) and an op-ed published by EURACTIV (2017). Government policies supporting the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) do not prevent friction, lack of mutual understanding and cultural clashes with the private sector. We argue that this relational issue is a neglected concern, albeit readily recognized by practitioners. In discussing public–private relations, this project points to a theoretical and practical challenge. Apart from analysing relevant literatures, we have benefited from varied data collection with input from policy makers, diplomats, business representatives and consulted experts across cultures.

projects.title: Diplomacy and the Duty of Care
projects.description: How can society be secured when important parts of, and interests of, the same society are located outside of state borders? Two articles, dealing with the impact of digitization on assistance to citizens abroad and on public-private collaboration in international crises, have been published in GLOBAL AFFAIRS (2016, see publications). THE HAGUE JOURNAL OF DIPLOMACY has produced a special issue in 2018 (13:2), guest edited by Maaike IOkano-Heijmans and Jan Melissen. Our research is part of a consortium effort led by the Norwegian Institute of International Affairs.

projects.title: Critical Digital Diplomacy as a Global Challenge: South Korea's Experience
projects.description: This project examines the South Korean experience in digital diplomacy. Our research has been published in GLOBAL POLICY (2017). Field research in Korea was an important part of the project, which includes collaboration with think tanks, universities, and government institutions in Seoul. This project has been funded by the Korea Foundation. It looks at how the Korean case can potentially enhance our understanding of diplomacy in the digital age.
